QA.answer: No, you cannot set up Direct Debits from Jars. You must use your main balances for that purpose.

QA.question: Are there any restrictions on using Jars in Singapore?
QA.answer: Yes, if you have a personal account with an address in Singapore, you can only use Jars when you invest in Assets.

QA.question: How do I close my balances?
QA.answer: To close your balances, first withdraw all money from the balance and then go to Home, select the balance, click on the three dots (...) and then select 'Close balance'.

QA.question: How can I withdraw money from my balance?
QA.answer: To withdraw money, go to Home, select the balance you want to withdraw from, select 'Send', choose the bank account you want to send the money to, choose 'Send it all', and confirm the payment to empty your balance.

QA.question: What happens to my Direct Debits when I close a balance?
QA.answer: When you close a balance, any Direct Debits set up will automatically be cancelled. This doesn't cancel the contract or subscription with the company you were paying, so make sure to cancel with them or give them different bank details.

QA.question: Will I still owe money to a company if I close a balance with Direct Debits set up?
QA.answer: Yes, closing a balance doesn't cancel the contract or subscription with the company. You might still owe them money and need to provide different bank details or cancel the contract to avoid extra fees.

QA.question: What fee am I charged to hold large amounts of EUR?
QA.answer: We don't charge any fees for holding large amounts of EUR on your account, except if you have an Australian address.

QA.question: I was charged a EUR holding fee in August 2022, why?
QA.answer: From December 2020 to August 2022, we charged a fee for holding large amounts of EUR due to negative interest rates in the Eurozone. The charge was removed in August 2022, but if you were charged on the 1st of August, it was to cover the holding fee for the previous month.

QA.question: What were the old EUR holding fee thresholds?
QA.answer: Up to 3,000 EUR for free for personal customers and up to 30,000 EUR for free for business customers.

QA.question: How were old EUR holding fees calculated?
QA.answer: Anything above the free allowance had a 0.9% annual fee charged on a monthly basis.

QA.question: What if I'm holding money as stocks?
QA.answer: If you hold any EUR as stocks, you won't be charged any fees. As of now, holding money as stocks in your Wise account is available for customers based in the UK.

QA.question: Are there any fees for holding large amounts of EUR if I live in Australia?
QA.answer: Yes, there are fees for holding large amounts of EUR on your account if you have an Australian address. Learn more about fees when you live in Australia.

QA.question: How can I set up Direct Debits?
QA.answer: Setting up Direct Debits is not mentioned in the provided text. Please provide more information or contact customer support for assistance.

QA.question: How can I use assets with my account?
QA.answer: Using assets with your account is not mentioned in the provided text. Please provide more information or contact customer support for assistance.

QA.question: What is the fee for holding large amounts of money in Australia?
QA.answer: The annual fee for holding large amounts is 1.6% for all currencies except Euros, which are charged at 0.4% annually.

QA.question: Why am I charged a fee for holding large amounts of money?
QA.answer: The fee contributes to our capital as per Australia's PPF regulations, allowing us to let you hold large amounts in your account.

QA.question: How much can I hold before getting charged?
QA.answer: Each currency has its own free allowance limit, including the balance and any amount held in a jar.

QA.question: Do the allowances in my personal and business account affect each other?
QA.answer: No, the amounts you hold in your personal account do not affect the free allowances in your business account, and vice versa.

QA.question: When does the fee for holding large amounts apply?
QA.answer: If you go over your free allowance for more than 3 days, we'll start charging the annual fee.

QA.question: How is the fee calculated?
QA.answer: The fee is calculated daily at approximately 0.00437% for all currencies except Euros, which have a daily fee of approximately 0.00109%.

QA.question: When will I be charged for holding large amounts?
QA.answer: We'll add up your daily fees and take the total from your account at the end of each month.

QA.question: What are the free allowances for AUD, EUR, GBP, and USD?
What is the holding limit for Japanese users?
QA.answer: The holding limit for Japanese users is 1 million JPY across all currencies in your Wise Balances and Jars.

QA.question: Am I considered a Japanese user?
QA.answer: You are considered a Japanese user if you have registered your Wise account with a Japanese address.

QA.question: How does Wise calculate my holding balance?
QA.answer: Wise uses the mid-market rate to convert all your non-JPY balances to JPY to determine your total balance in JPY.

QA.question: What is the grace period to withdraw my extra balance if it exceeds the holding limit?
QA.answer: You have 30 days to withdraw your extra balance if it exceeds the holding limit of 1 million JPY.

QA.question: How do I set up an external account with Wise?
QA.answer: To set up an external account, log in to the Wise website, go to Recipients, and add or select the bank account you'd want to mark as your external account.

QA.question: What are the requirements for my external account?
QA.answer: Your external account must be under your ownership, in JPY, and not your own Wise Account.

QA.question: What happens if I don't withdraw my excess funds within 30 days?
QA.answer: If you don't withdraw your excess funds within 30 days, your account will be restricted and you won't be able to deposit and receive funds into your account.

QA.question: How can I lift the restriction on my account?
QA.answer: To lift the restriction on your account, set up your external account or manually transfer the excess funds out from your balance. Once your excess funds are transferred out, your account restrictions will be lifted.

QA.question: Will I receive funds sent to me while my account was restricted?
QA.answer: Yes, you will receive any funds from third parties after your account restrictions have been lifted.

QA.question: What is the holding limit for personal accounts in Malaysia?
QA.answer: The holding limit for personal accounts is 20,000 MYR.

QA.question: Are there holding limits for business accounts in Malaysia?
QA.answer: No, there are no limits to how much you can hold in your Wise business account.

QA.question: How does Wise calculate a customer's holding balance?
QA.answer: Wise converts all your non-MYR balances to MYR using the mid-market rate and adds them to your MYR balance to determine your total balance in MYR.

QA.question: What should I do if my holding balance exceeds the limit?
QA.answer: You'll need to set up an external account for Wise to automatically send your excess funds to, or you can manually transfer the funds out of your account.

QA.question: What are the consequences of not having an external account set up?
QA.answer: If you don't have an external account set up and your balance exceeds 20,000 MYR, your account will be restricted and you won't be able to deposit and receive funds.

QA.question: How do I set up an external account in Wise?
QA.answer: Log in to the Wise website, go to Recipients, and add or select the bank account you'd want to mark as your external account.

QA.question: What happens if my account is restricted?
QA.answer: You won't be able to deposit and receive funds into your account. Set up your external account or manually transfer the excess funds out to lift the restriction.

QA.question: Will I receive funds sent during the restricted period?
QA.answer: Yes, you'll receive these funds after your account restrictions have been lifted.

QA.question: How do I add money to a balance?
QA.answer: You can add money to your balance either through your Wise account or directly from your bank account via a direct deposit/bank transfer.

QA.question: What are the steps to add money to my balance through my Wise account?
QA.answer: 1. Go to the balance you'd like to add money to. 2. Click 'Add.' 3. Choose the amount and currency you'd like to pay with. 4. Select the payment method and click 'Continue' to payment. 5. Follow the guided payment steps.

QA.question: Can I add money to my Wise account from any bank account?
QA.answer: No, the money needs to come from a bank account that matches the name on your Wise account. If you have a Wise account for your business, the bank account should be under the business name.

QA.question: Are there any currencies I cannot add money in?
QA.answer: Yes, you cannot add money in AED, BDT, CLP, CRC, EGP, HKD, GEL, IDR, ILS, INR, KES, MXN, LKR, NGN, NPR, MAD, PEN, PHP, PKR, RUB, THB, UAH, VND, ZAR, and CNY. You can add money in available currencies and then convert to these currencies.

QA.question: How do I add money to my balance from my bank account?
QA.answer: Log in to your online banking, set up a normal transfer, and use the account details from your Wise account. Make sure to send the same currency as your balance is in.

QA.question: Do I need to set up a top-up in Wise before adding money via bank transfer?
QA.answer: No, you don't need to set up a top-up in Wise if you're adding money via a direct deposit/bank transfer.

QA.question: Which currencies can I set up Direct Debits from?
QA.answer: You can set up Direct Debits from AUD, CAD, GBP, EUR, and USD accounts.

QA.question: How do I find my Wise account details in the app?
QA.answer: Go to Home and tap the balance at the top of the screen.

QA.question: How do I find my Wise account details on the Wise website?
QA.answer: Go to Manage and choose the balance you want to send from.

QA.question: Can non-US residents use a USD account for Direct Debits?
QA.answer: Yes, but only if your account details have a routing number starting with '084'.

QA.question: Does Wise support EUR account Direct Debits made via the SEPA B2B direct debit scheme?
QA.answer: No, Wise doesn't support EUR account Direct Debits made via the SEPA B2B direct debit scheme.

QA.question: What should I do after giving my Wise account details to the company?
QA.answer: Wait a day or two for the company to set up the Direct Debit and check that they'll set it up electronically.

QA.question: What if I don't hold the currency needed for the Direct Debit?
QA.answer: Wise will automatically convert the currency for you from the balance with the lowest possible conversion fee.

QA.question: Will I be charged for setting up Direct Debit payments?
QA.answer: It's free to set up Direct Debit payments, unless you're paying from a different currency, in which case the normal conversion fee applies.

QA.question: Are there any fees for rejected Direct Debit payments?
QA.answer: Wise doesn't charge any fees for rejected payments.

QA.question: How can I hold money in my account?
QA.answer: You can hold money in your account by holding balances, setting up Direct Debits, and using Assets.

QA.question: How can I view my existing Direct Debits on the website?
QA.answer: 1. Go to Manage, 2. Select one of your balances, 3. Select Direct Debits.

QA.question: How can I view my existing Direct Debits on the app?
QA.answer: 1. Tap on Account, 2. Select Direct Debits from the list of Account services (under the debit card).

QA.question: How can I cancel a Direct Debit?
QA.answer: You can cancel a Direct Debit from the Direct Debits page on either the website or app.

QA.question: How can I find my Direct Debits on the website?
QA.answer: Go to Manage, click on one of your balances, and click on Direct Debits.

QA.question: How can I find my Direct Debits on the app?
QA.answer: Go to Account, under Account services, tap on Direct Debits.

QA.question: How do I cancel a Direct Debit?
QA.answer: Go to your Direct Debits, choose the Direct Debit you want to cancel, and select Cancel Direct Debit.

QA.question: When should I cancel a Direct Debit to prevent it from going through?
QA.answer: Cancel at least 1 working day before your payment is due.

QA.question: Will cancelling a Direct Debit cancel my contract or subscription with the company?
QA.answer: No, cancelling a Direct Debit won't cancel the contract or subscription. You need to cancel with them or give them different account details.

QA.question: What currencies are supported for Direct Debits?
QA.answer: Direct Debits are available for AUD, CAD, EUR, GBP, and USD accounts.

QA.question: What are some reasons my Direct Debit may have failed?
QA.answer: Reasons include: unsupported currency, insufficient funds, cancellation by you, issues with merchant setup, or Direct Debits not allowed in your country.

QA.question: How can I find out why my Direct Debit failed?
QA.answer: Go to Home in your account and find the failed transaction for more information.

QA.question: What should I do if my Direct Debit fails?
QA.answer: Contact your merchant to learn more and arrange another way to pay.

QA.question: Can I get a reimbursement for a rejected debit fee?
QA.answer: No, we cannot reimburse you for a rejected debit fee charged by your merchant.

QA.question: Can I request a refund for my Direct Debit?
QA.answer: Yes, you can request a refund for your Direct Debit, depending on the currency and the specific circumstances. Contact the merchant directly if you have issues with the goods or services, or email disputes@wise.com if there was a technical error with the transaction.

QA.question: What are some examples of technical errors for which I can request a refund?
QA.answer: Some examples of technical errors include being charged double, being charged after cancelling the Direct Debit, or never setting up a payment to that merchant.

QA.question: What is the refund deadline for EUR Direct Debit payments?
QA.answer: You can request a refund for EUR Direct Debit payments up to 8 weeks from the date the payment was made.

QA.question: What is the deadline for requesting a refund for CAD Direct Debit payments?
QA.answer: For CAD Direct Debit payments on a personal balance, you have up to 90 days; for business balance, you have 10 working days to request a refund.

QA.question: What is the deadline for requesting a refund for USD Direct Debit payments?
QA.answer: For USD Direct Debit payments on a personal balance, you have up to 60 days; for business balance, you have 2 working days to request a refund.

QA.question: How do I request a refund for a EUR Direct Debit payment less than 8 weeks old?
QA.answer: For EUR Direct Debits less than 8 weeks old, request a refund by selecting the transaction on your Home page and clicking on 'Request a refund'. This option is only available on the web.

QA.question: Is Assets available to everyone?
QA.answer: No, currently Assets is only available to some UK, Singapore, and EEA residents and most businesses that are tax residents in the UK.

QA.question: How can I hold my money with Assets?
QA.answer: With Assets, you can choose to hold your money in Cash, Interest or Stocks for your Balances or Jars.

QA.question: How do I switch between Cash, Interest and Stocks?
QA.answer: To switch, go to the Balance or Jar you want to change and select the Cash, Stocks or Interest icon.

QA.question: How long does it take to change the way my money is held?
QA.answer: The change can take up to 2 working days, and may take an extra working day if you have transactions in progress or if a change is still being processed.

QA.question: What happens when I hold my money as Cash?
QA.answer: Holding money as Cash means it does not grow, but it is not at risk in the market and is covered by our safeguarding policy.

QA.question: What happens when I hold my money as Stocks?
QA.answer: Holding money as Stocks means we will invest your money in the Jar or Balance in the index tracking fund we've chosen.

QA.question: What happens when I hold my money as Interest?
QA.answer: Holding money as Interest means we will invest your money in the Jar or Balance in the interest-earning fund we've chosen depending on the currency.

QA.question: Who can use the Assets feature?
QA.answer: Assets is available to consumers and businesses that are residents in the UK, EEA (specific countries), and Singapore. Availability differs depending on the country of residence.

QA.question: What funds can I invest in if I'm a resident in the UK?
QA.answer: UK residents can invest in: iShares World Equity Index Fund, BlackRock ICS Sterling Government Liquidity Fund, BlackRock ICS Euro Government Liquidity Fund, and BlackRock ICS US Treasury Fund.

QA.question: Which EEA countries currently support the Assets feature?
QA.answer: Austria, France, Finland, Luxembourg, Netherlands, and Spain.

QA.question: What funds can EEA residents invest in?
QA.answer: EEA residents can invest in: BlackRock ICS Sterling Government Liquidity Fund and BlackRock ICS Euro Government Liquidity Fund.

QA.question: What funds can Singapore residents invest in?
QA.answer: Singapore residents can invest in LionGlobal SGD Money Market Fund.

QA.question: Can I use Assets if I'm a US citizen or taxpayer?
QA.answer: No, US citizens or taxpayers cannot use Assets due to regulatory restrictions on the fund partner.

QA.question: What happens to my invested money if I move countries?
QA.answer: Your money will remain invested, but you might not be able to add more or reinvest until you move back to a country where Assets is available. Exceptions are the US and Brazil where your investments would be sold and switched back to cash.

QA.question: How can I switch between Cash and Assets?
QA.answer: You can switch between Cash and Assets by selecting the Cash icon on your Balance or Jar.

QA.question: What taxes do I need to pay when I use Assets?
QA.answer: You might have to pay tax on your earnings from Assets, depending on the tax laws in the countries you’re a tax resident in and how much money you’ve made or lost across all of your investments. Many countries require you to pay capital gains tax.

QA.question: How do I find out my taxable earnings from Assets?
QA.answer: To find out how much money you’ve made or lost using Assets, you can download a stocks tax report from your account. Go to the Account section, select Statements, and then select Stocks tax report.

QA.question: Do I need to report my share of any income that the fund makes?
QA.answer: Yes, depending on the tax laws in your country, you may need to report your share of any income that the fund makes, in the form of dividends or interest, depending on the underlying assets of the fund.

QA.question: What tax information does Wise collect?
QA.answer: When you start using Assets, Wise is required to ask where you’re a tax resident, which is the country where you usually live and pay tax. Depending on where you live, Wise might also ask for your tax identification number.

QA.question: Does Wise share tax information with anyone?
QA.answer: Wise will only share your tax information with relevant government tax authorities if needed. This is to comply with international tax standards like the Common Reporting Standard (CRS) or the Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (FATCA).

QA.question: Is my money safe using Assets?
QA.answer: Yes, your money is safe using Assets. Wise Assets holds customers' fund units segregated from any corporate assets, ensuring their protection in the event of insolvency. Additionally, Wise is subject to Estonian, UK, or Singapore regulations depending on your location, and undergoes an annual external audit by PwC.

QA.question: What happens if Wise becomes insolvent?
QA.answer: If Wise becomes insolvent, your assets are held separately from any of Wise's other corporate assets, and insolvency practitioners would not be permitted to use these assets to cover outstanding debts. Wise keeps detailed records of all customers' investments, which would enable the insolvency practitioner to identify and return your assets to you or transfer them to a different provider.

QA.question: What happens if the fund provider (BlackRock) becomes insolvent?
QA.answer: In the unlikely event of BlackRock becoming insolvent, the underlying assets (e.g., shares of companies that make up the index) are not held by BlackRock itself. A third party (the depositary or trustee) looks after the fund's underlying assets, ensuring their protection from creditors if the fund manager goes bankrupt.

QA.question: Is my investment protected?
QA.answer: Yes, your investment is protected. In addition to the strict segregation of customers' assets, the Estonian Investor Protection Sectoral Fund covers your assets for up to €20,000 (if you're in the EEA), and the Financial Services Compensation Scheme ('FSCS') protects each customer for up to £85,000 (if you're in the UK).

QA.question: What are the annual external audits and who performs them?
QA.answer: Annual external audits are inspections to assess if Wise operates in line with the relevant regulations. These audits are performed by PwC - an accounting and professional services firm.

QA.question: Which regulations apply to Wise Assets?
QA.answer: The applicable regulations depend on your location: Estonian regulations apply to EEA customers, FCA regulations apply to UK customers, and Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) requirements apply to Singaporean customers.

QA.question: What are Direct Debits?
QA.answer: Direct Debits are a convenient way to make recurring payments to businesses or individuals directly from your bank account. Many customers use Direct Debits for things like utility bills, mortgage or rent payments, and subscriptions.

QA.question: What regulator is responsible for accounts in the EEA?
QA.answer: TINV EUROPE AS is authorised and regulated as an investment firm by the Estonian Financial Supervision Authority (Finantsinspektsioon).

QA.question: Under which regulator are the UK-based accounts?
QA.answer: TINV is authorised and regulated by the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) under FSMA for the provision of investment services.

QA.question: Which license does Wise Asia-Pacific Pte. Ltd. hold in Singapore?
QA.answer: Wise Asia-Pacific Pte. Ltd. is licensed by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) as a major payment institution and holds a Capital Markets Services Licence under the SFA.

QA.question: How does my address on Wise account affect the license for holding assets?
QA.answer: The license depends on the asset you are holding and the address you had on your Wise account when you switched a Balance or Jar to an asset other than Cash.

QA.question: Are accounts and Jars held as Cash subject to the same licenses as those held as Stocks or Interest?
QA.answer: No, accounts and Jars held as Cash are always subjected to our payments institution / e-money licences, while Balances and Jars held as Stocks or Interest operate under our investment licences.

QA.question: What do I need to know if I have an address in the EU and switch assets from Cash to Stocks?
QA.answer: You will be engaging with TINV Europe AS, an authorised EU investment firm regulated by the Estonian Financial Supervision Authority (Finantsinspektsioon).

QA.question: Can I set up Direct Debits on my Wise account?
QA.answer: Yes, you can set up Direct Debits on your Wise account.

QA.question: How do I make a complaint if my Balance or Jar is held as Assets?
QA.answer: Send us an email with your Wise membership number (beginning with P), the subject of your complaint, and what you would like us to do to fix it. We will investigate and respond within 14 calendar days.

QA.question: What is the timeline to expect a response after submitting a complaint?
QA.answer: We will send you a final response within 14 calendar days.

QA.question: Can I escalate my complaint to a dispute body?
QA.answer: Yes, if you are unhappy with our decision, you can escalate it to the relevant dispute body based on the address you had on your Wise account at the time you switched a currency account or Jar to Stocks.

QA.question: Who do I contact if my complaint is related to an address in the UK?
QA.answer: If your address was in the UK, contact the Financial Ombudsman Service (FOS) via their website, email, mail, or phone.

QA.question: Who do I contact if my complaint is related to an address in the EEA?
QA.answer: If your address was in the EEA, you can make a complaint to the Consumer Disputes Committee in Estonia. You can file a complaint via the Online Dispute Resolution environment, email, or mail.

QA.question: Who do I contact if my complaint is related to an address in Singapore?
QA.answer: If your address was in Singapore, contact Fidrec via their website, email, address, or phone.

QA.question: What options do I have for holding my money in Balances or Jars?
QA.answer: Currently, you can choose Cash, Interest or Stocks.

QA.question: What happens if I choose to hold my money as Stocks?
QA.answer: We'll invest all of the Balance or Jar in a fund we've chosen, the iShares World Equity Index Fund, managed by BlackRock.

QA.question: What companies are included in the MSCI World Index?
QA.answer: It includes some of the world's biggest companies, like Apple, Tesla, and Microsoft.

QA.question: Is there a risk involved when investing in Stocks?
QA.answer: Yes, your money is at risk whenever you invest, but in funds like this, that risk is spread.

QA.question: What fees do I pay when investing using my Wise account?
QA.answer: You pay a service fee to Wise (0.40% annually) and a fund fee to BlackRock (0.15% annually).

QA.question: How are the fees charged when investing using my Wise account?
QA.answer: Both fees are taken automatically.

QA.question: How much of my invested Balance or Jar can I access at any given time?
QA.answer: You can send, spend or withdraw up to 97% of your invested Balance or Jar.

QA.question: What happens when I add or receive money in my Balance or Jar held as Stocks?
QA.answer: We'll invest the money by buying units worth the same cash value. We buy units once every working day at 07:00 UK time. It can take up to 2 working days to complete a buy order for your units.

QA.question: How can I take money out from my Balance or Jar held as Stocks?
QA.answer: You can instantly access up to 97% of your Balance or Jar by 1. Spending with your Wise card, 2. Sending money from your Balance, 3. Moving money to a different Balance or Jar.

QA.question: What happens when I spend or send money from my Balance or Jar held as Stocks?
QA.answer: We'll sell some of your investment units worth the cash value of the transaction at the next trading cut-off time, which is 07:00 UK time. It can take up to 2 working days to complete the sale.

QA.question: Why can I only take out up to 97% of my Balance or Jar when it's held as Stocks?
QA.answer: We reserve the other 3% to cover any large changes to the value of your investment, reducing the chances of your Balance going into negative.

QA.question: What is the difference between total amount and available amount in my Balance or Jar held as Stocks?
QA.answer: Total amount is the current worth of your Balance or Jar, including the valuation of your investment units and any uninvested money. Available amount is the money you can spend, send, or withdraw instantly, including uninvested money and 97% of any invested money.

QA.question: How do I avoid accidentally investing recently added money?
QA.answer: Withdraw the money before the next trading cut-off time, which is 07:00 UK time.

QA.question: What are units in the context of holding Stocks?
QA.answer: Units represent a slice of the investment fund. The price of a unit can go up or down daily, depending on the fund's performance. Buying units when their price is low and selling when the price goes up represents growth in your investment.

QA.question: How often do you update the valuation of my investment?
QA.answer: We update the valuation of your investment based on the price of your units at the start of every working day.

QA.question: How can I access all of the money in my Balance or Jar held as Stocks?
QA.answer: You'll need to change it back to cash. This can take up to 2 working days, plus extra time if you have transactions in progress.

QA.question: What fees do I pay when I hold money as stocks?
QA.answer: You pay two fees when you hold your money as stocks: a service fee (0.4% annual fee charged as 0.033% monthly fee) and a fund fee (0.15% annually charged by BlackRock).

QA.question: Are there any restrictions on who can use Stocks?
QA.answer: Right now, Stocks is only available to UK residents and most businesses that are tax resident in the UK.

QA.question: How is the service fee calculated?
QA.answer: The service fee is calculated daily based on the amount you hold as stocks in your Balances and Jars. It's charged on the 1st day of the following month.

QA.question: Can the service fee be charged to Jars?
QA.answer: No, the service fee will be taken from a Balance, not charged to Jars.

QA.question: Where does the fund fee come from?
QA.answer: BlackRock charges the fund fee, which is 0.15% annually. It’s automatically reflected in the value of your investment.

QA.question: Is there an entry fee for Wise customers?
QA.answer: No, the entry fee mentioned in the Key Investor Information Document is not charged to Wise customers.

QA.question: Do I need to pay trading fees?
QA.answer: No, you don’t need to pay any trading fees to cover your investment transactions, as Wise charges a service fee.

QA.question: Are there any conversion fees for holding money in stocks?
QA.answer: You won't pay a conversion fee when holding money as stocks. However, you'll pay a conversion fee if you add money to your account or Jar and it's in a different currency.

QA.question: What is the iShares World Equity Index Fund?
QA.answer: The iShares World Equity Index Fund is an index-tracking fund managed by BlackRock, which invests in company shares in the developed world.

QA.question: What is the risk rating of the iShares World Equity Index Fund?
QA.answer: The iShares World Equity Index Fund has a risk rating of 6 out of 7, with 0 being least risky and 7 being most risky.

QA.question: How does an index-tracking fund work?
QA.answer: Index-tracking funds buy stocks in all the companies in an index, which are hypothetical portfolios of stocks that represent different markets.

QA.question: Which index does the iShares World Equity Index Fund track?
QA.answer: The iShares World Equity Index Fund tracks the MSCI World Index, representing the stock market of developed countries and stocks in over 1500 companies.

QA.question: What are some examples of companies in the MSCI World Index?
QA.answer: The MSCI World Index includes stocks from biggest companies in the world, like Apple, Microsoft, and Tesla.

QA.question: What are the potential benefits and risks of investing in the iShares World Equity Index Fund?
QA.answer: Investing in the iShares World Equity Index Fund can produce good returns in the long term but is not guaranteed, and the value of the fund may fluctuate more often in the short term.

QA.question: Should I invest in the iShares World Equity Index Fund if I'm not comfortable with the risk?
QA.answer: You should only invest if you are comfortable with the possibility of losing some money and consider investment as a long-term decision.

QA.question: Can Wise give me advice about investments?
QA.answer: Wise isn't able to give you advice about investments. You should speak to an independent financial adviser and/or conduct your own research if you're not sure about investing in the index fund.

QA.question: How can I check the performance of my investment using the app?
QA.answer: 1. Log into your Wise account in the app. 2. Go to your currency account or jar held as Stocks. 3. Click on the Stocks icon. You will see your gains graph and the fund performance graph.

QA.question: What are the two types of gains represented on the gains graph?
QA.answer: The gains graph represents both 'realised' and 'unrealised' gains.

QA.question: How are realised gains calculated?
QA.answer: Realised gains are calculated from the units you have sold to send money, withdraw or spend from Stocks. The accumulation of the differences between fund performances from the day you started investing to a given date is the realised gains up to that date.

QA.question: How are unrealised gains calculated?
QA.answer: Unrealised gains are calculated from the units you have remaining as Stocks. It looks at the difference between the price of the units on a particular day and the prices of those units on the day they were purchased.

QA.question: How can I access my earnings from my investment?
QA.answer: To access your earnings, you just need to spend your money held as Stocks. When you spend or send from your account, we sell the equivalent number of units. There's no need to divest the balance or Jar held as Stocks.

QA.question: What is the Earnings since start line in the statements?
QA.answer: Earnings since start is the difference between holding money as Stocks versus Cash since the day you started investing in this currency account or jar. It compares the value of your currency account or jar using the fund price on the last day to a summation of all historical cash transactions.

QA.question: How can I check the performance of my investment using the Standard and Accounting statement?
QA.answer: Find the reports by clicking ... or More... on the currency account or jar page, and selecting the option of Statements. Look for the Earnings since start line.

QA.question: What factors can impact the performance of a balance or jar held as Stocks?
QA.answer: Factors affecting the performance include moving money to and from the balance or jar held as Stocks, the price of the unit when you buy or sell your investment, and the exchange rate of different currencies.

QA.question: How can I read the fund performance graph for Stocks?
QA.answer: The fund performance graph tracks the relative change in the fund day after day. The performance of Stocks fund tracks the MSCI world index. Changes you see here reflect the relative changes to that index. Bear in mind that past performance and projections don't guarantee future growth.

QA.question: What currency are units of the iShares World Equity index fund bought and sold in?
QA.answer: Units of the iShares World Equity index fund are bought and sold in Euros (EUR).

QA.question: What happens when I switch a Balance or Jar held in a currency other than EUR to Stocks?
QA.answer: A conversion will apply when you buy or sell units, as the balance is converted to or from EUR.

QA.question: Are there any conversion fees when buying or selling units of the iShares World Equity index fund?
QA.answer: You won't pay any conversion fees when buying or selling units of the fund, and the mid-market rate will be used.

QA.question: How does the exchange rate impact the value and performance of my Stocks holding?
QA.answer: The exchange rate affects the relative value in different currencies, gains and losses, and the performance of your investment compared to the performance of the fund.

QA.question: Which currencies are most affected by the impact of exchange rates?
QA.answer: Currencies that tend to fluctuate a lot against the Euro are most affected by the impact of exchange rates.

QA.question: Is my balance being converted to USD as the fund's base currency?
QA.answer: No, the fund's base currency (USD) does not impact your investment or returns. Only a conversion to and from EUR applies when buying or selling units.

QA.question: What is the impact of holding money in Stocks for UK taxpayers?
QA.answer: If you're a UK taxpayer, holding your money in Stocks can impact the way you pay tax. What you need to report to HMRC is determined by your circumstances.

QA.question: What's the difference between UK and non-UK investment funds?
QA.answer: UK investment funds are required to distribute any income they earn, while offshore funds don't have this requirement. Offshore funds that comply with the UK Reporting Fund regime are likely to retain any earned income, known as Excess Reportable Income (ERI).

QA.question: Are Wise Assets considered UK reporting funds?
QA.answer: Yes, currently, Wise only offers UK reporting funds.

QA.question: How does Excess Reportable Income affect capital gains?
QA.answer: For UK tax residents, any gain from the disposal of an investment in a reporting fund is subject to capital gains tax. The ERI amounts subjected to income tax should generally be added to the base cost of the investment. This will reduce the gain subject to capital gains tax.

QA.question: What is the impact of the Wise Assets to UK taxpayers?
QA.answer: The underlying assets of any UK reporting fund determine how HMRC will treat any ERI or distributed income from the fund. The iShares World Equity Index Fund (ISIN: LU0852473015) is primarily composed of equity securities, so any ERI earned by this fund should be considered as dividend income. ERI is eligible for annual allowances in the UK.

QA.question: When is the self-assessment and payment deadline for UK individual taxpayers?
QA.answer: The self-assessment and payment deadline for UK individual taxpayers is 31 January of the following year.

QA.question: When does the iShares World Equity Index Fund accounting year end?
QA.answer: The iShares World Equity Index Fund (ISIN: LU0852473015) has an accounting year end of 31 March.

QA.question: When is the income from the iShares World Equity Index Fund deemed to be distributed?
QA.answer: The income from the iShares World Equity Index Fund (ISIN: LU0852473015) is deemed to be distributed on 30 September, 6 months after the accounting year ends.

QA.question: What is the UK Self-assessment and how do I know if it applies to me?
QA.answer: Self-assessment is used by the UK tax authority (HMRC) to collect tax from individuals. It applies if you meet certain criteria, such as earning income from non-UK sources or working for yourself. Check the requirements on HMRC's website.

QA.question: What are the deadlines to submit a self-assessment tax return?
QA.answer: The UK tax year runs from 6 April to 5 April of the following year. The filing deadline for self-assessment tax returns is 31 January following the end of the tax year.

QA.question: How do I register to file a self-assessment tax return?
QA.answer: You'll need to complete HMRC’s form SA1 and return it to HMRC. Once they check the form, you'll get a self-assessment record and a Unique Taxpayer Reference (UTR) number.

QA.question: What happens if I don't file my tax return by the deadline?
QA.answer: HMRC might issue a penalty to you. There's an automatic 100 GBP penalty if you don't file your tax return by 31 January, and additional penalties may apply until you submit the return. HMRC also charges interest on late-paid tax.

QA.question: What should I do if I no longer meet the criteria for filing a UK tax return?
QA.answer: If you no longer meet the criteria for self-assessment, you should de-register. If you don't do this, you may have to pay a penalty to HMRC for any unsubmitted tax returns. Contact HMRC to de-register from the self-assessment system.

QA.question: Can I still use my money in the same way if I switch to Interest?
QA.answer: Yes, switching to Interest doesn't change what you can do with your money.

QA.question: Which Money Market Funds will my money be invested in if my address is in the UK or European Economic Area?
QA.answer: For GBP, it'll be invested in BlackRock ICS Sterling Government Liquidity Fund Premier Acc, for EUR in BlackRock ICS Euro Government Liquidity Fund Premier Acc T0, and for USD in BlackRock ICS US Treasury Fund Premier ACC.

QA.question: How often are units bought or sold in the Money Market Funds?
QA.answer: Units are bought or sold once per day.

QA.question: When is the trading cut-off time for the Money Market Funds in the UK or European Economic Area?
QA.answer: The trading cut-off time is 7:00 AM GMT.

QA.question: When is the trading cut-off time for the MMF LionGlobal SGD Money Market Fund for customers in Singapore?
QA.answer: The trading cut-off time is 2:30 pm SGT.

QA.question: How long does it take to complete a buy or sell order for units in the funds?
QA.answer: It can take up to 2 working days to complete a buy or sell order for your units.

QA.question: How can I see my gains from holding my money as Interest?
QA.answer: Click on the Interest button on your balance or Jar to see what you've gained since switching it to Interest.

QA.question: Is earning interest on Wise account available for US customers?
QA.answer: Interest-earning funds are currently not available for US customers, but you might still be eligible to earn interest on your money if you live in the US.

QA.question: Can I switch to Wise Interest from a balance or Jar?
QA.answer: Yes, you can switch to Wise Interest from a balance or Jar in certain currencies if you're eligible.

QA.question: Is the Wise Interest feature available for US customers?
QA.answer: Currently, Wise Interest is not available for US customers. However, you can still earn interest on your money if you live in the US.

QA.question: What happens when I switch to Interest?
QA.answer: Your money is kept in a fund holding government-backed short-term loans. The interest from those loans is passed on to you. The fund is low-risk and tracks the interest rate offered by the central bank of the currency it's in.

QA.question: Are there risks involved when I switch to Interest?
QA.answer: The main risks include the government defaulting or interest rates dropping to 0% or lower. While your investment is not guaranteed, the risk is generally considered low.

QA.question: Are there limits and timeframes for accessing my invested money?
QA.answer: Yes, limits and timeframes for accessing your money will depend on your country of residency.

QA.question: Where can I learn more about the securities held by the interest-earning funds?
QA.answer: Visit BlackRock's EUR, GBP, and USD fund pages to learn more about the securities, risk, performance, portfolio characteristics, Key Investor Information Document (KIID), holdings, and maturity.

QA.question: How can I check the performance of my Assets?
QA.answer: Log into your Wise account in the app, go to your Balance or Jar held as Interest, and click on the Interest button. The return you've made since switching will be shown in green.

QA.question: What is a Money Market Fund (MMF)?
QA.answer: A Money Market Fund (MMF) is a type of investment fund that invests in low-risk liquid assets. The returns generated by these assets are linked to the interest rate set by the central bank of the fund's currency.

QA.question: What determines the rate of return of a Money Market Fund?
QA.answer: The rate of return of a Money Market Fund broadly mirrors the interest rate set by the central bank of the fund's currency, such as the Federal Reserve for USD MMF or the European Central Bank for EUR MMF.

QA.question: How do I access my standard and accounting statements?
QA.answer: Log into your Wise account in the app, go to your Balance or Jar held as Interest, click on More, select Statements and reports, and choose the type of statement you'd like to download.

QA.question: What is the significance of Earnings since start in my statement?
QA.answer: Earnings since start shows the difference between holding money as Interest vs. Cash since the day you started investing. A negative amount may appear if the price of the fund unit dropped since you invested your Balance or Jar.

QA.question: Do I need to pay taxes on my money held as Interest?
QA.answer: You may be liable to pay tax on any gains that are in excess of your relevant annual tax thresholds.

QA.question: What is Interest and why is it low risk?
QA.answer: Interest refers to holding money in funds known as 'public debt constant net asset value' (CNAV) short-term money market funds. These funds invest only in the safest securities, namely government securities. It is considered low risk because of the government backing and the funds' constant net asset value.

QA.question: Can I lose more money than I put in?
QA.answer: Interest funds are designed to maintain their capital and not go down in value. However, an investment is never guaranteed, and it's possible that the net asset value of a money market fund decreases. Scenarios include negative interest rates or governments going bankrupt, but these are extremely unlikely.

QA.question: What is the potential impact on my holdings in a worst case scenario?
QA.answer: Based on data from the last 10 years, the worst case scenario would result in the following after 1 year: $10,000 invested could be worth $9,990, £10,000 invested could be worth £9,990, and €10,000 invested could be worth €9,930. Please note that past performance does not guarantee future performance.

QA.question: What are the risks associated with holding money in Interest?
QA.answer: Although the funds hold assets backed by governments and are deemed to be very low risk, there are still risks, such as extreme volatility, which may temporarily restrict access to the fund to preserve the value of your investment.

QA.question: Are interest-earning funds available for US customers?
QA.answer: Interest-earning funds are currently not available for US customers, but you might be still eligible to earn interest on your money if you live in the US.

QA.question: What fees do I pay when I hold money in an interest-earning fund?
QA.answer: When you hold money in an interest-earning fund, you pay two fees: a service fee charged by Wise and a fund management fee charged by the fund manager.

QA.question: How is the service fee calculated?
QA.answer: The service fee is calculated daily, based on the amount you hold as Stocks or Interest in your Balances and Jars. It is charged on the 1st day of the following month.

QA.question: Which balance is the service fee charged to?
QA.answer: The service fee is charged to your Balance in the same currency, which can be held as Cash or Interest. If there's not enough money in that Balance, it is taken from another one that has money.

QA.question: What is the fund management fee?
QA.answer: The fund management fee is charged by the fund manager and is automatically reflected in the value of your investment. You won't see it as a separate fee in your account.

QA.question: Are there any other fees besides the service and fund fees?
QA.answer: You won't pay any other fees apart from the service and fund fees. However, you'll pay a conversion fee if you add money to your Balance or Jar in a different currency.

QA.question: Can US customers use interest-earning funds?
QA.answer: Interest-earning funds are not available for US customers, but they might still be eligible to earn interest on their money if they live in the US.

QA.question: Where is the Wise card available?
QA.answer: The Wise card is currently available for Wise account-holder residents in Australia, Brazil, the EEA, Japan, New Zealand, Singapore, Malaysia, Switzerland, the UK, the US, and Canada.

QA.question: How can I get my card details?
QA.answer: You can see your card number, expiry date, and CVV any time on the Wise app or website for cards issued in the UK, the EEA, Switzerland, Australia, New Zealand, Singapore, Japan, Malaysia, Canada, and Brazil. For US cardholders, card details are available in the app after activation.

QA.question: How do I activate my non-US Wise card?
QA.answer: For non-US cardholders, you just need to pay using your PIN. If the Chip and PIN payment gets declined, please use the card at an ATM for either cash withdrawal or balance enquiry.

QA.question: How do I activate my US Wise card?
QA.answer: To activate your US card, go to your Wise account in the app or website and enter the 6-digit code that’s on the card.

QA.question: How do I add money to my Wise account?
QA.answer: Open the Wise app, choose the currency you'd like to add money to, and how much you'd like to add. Then, choose to pay using different payment methods like bank transfer or card.

QA.question: How does Wise handle currency conversion on my card?
QA.answer: If you have the currency in your account, Wise deducts the amount for free. If you don't have the currency, Wise will automatically convert the amount for you using the cheapest conversion fee from your available balances.

QA.question: What should I do when an ATM or store offers to charge me in my home currency?
QA.answer: Always choose to be charged in the local currency of where you are, to avoid hidden fees and marked-up exchange rates.

QA.question: What are the free ATM withdrawal limits for Wise cards?
QA.answer: You have 2 free withdrawals every month up to certain amounts, depending on where your card is issued. Limits vary and you can track them in the app or on the website.

QA.question: What is the Wise Eco card?
QA.answer: The Wise Eco card is a new offering for residents of the UK or the EEA. It's designed to have a lower environmental impact than conventional cards.

QA.question: Can I get a digital card if I already have a physical card?
QA.answer: Yes, you can get a digital card if you already have a physical card and live in the UK, Australia, Japan, New Zealand, Singapore, Malaysia, Switzerland, EEA, Brazil or Canada.

QA.question: Do I need to activate my digital card?
QA.answer: No, your digital card is ready to be used the moment you’ve requested it. No activation or PIN is needed.

QA.question: How many digital cards can I have?
QA.answer: In addition to your physical card, you can have up to 3 digital cards at one time.

QA.question: Where can I find my digital card details?
QA.answer: You can find your card numbers, expiry date, and CVV in the app or website.

QA.question: Can I replace or delete my digital card details?
QA.answer: Yes, you can generate new card details whenever you want.

QA.question: What payment methods are available with my digital card?
QA.answer: Your digital cards can be used with your mobile wallet in-store or for online payments.

QA.question: Are the fees for spending with a digital card different from a physical card?
QA.answer: No, you will pay the same low and transparent fees that you're used to when using your digital card.

QA.question: What is the Wise eco card made of?
QA.answer: The Wise eco card is made of biodegradable material to reduce plastic waste.

QA.question: How can I check my full card details for the Wise eco card?
QA.answer: You can check your full card details on your Wise account.

QA.question: Who can order the Wise eco card?
QA.answer: Personal customers in the EEA and the UK can order the Wise eco card.

QA.question: How can I order a Wise eco card?
QA.answer: Click on the Cards tab on your account to order a Wise eco card.

QA.question: Can I order an Eco card if I already have a standard Wise card?
QA.answer: Yes, you can order an Eco card as a second card. Your Wise card will continue to work until the expiry date.

QA.question: Can I replace an expiring standard Wise card with an Eco card?
QA.answer: No, you can’t replace an expiring standard Wise card with an Eco card. You need to order them separately.

QA.question: Can I use the Eco card everywhere the standard Wise card is accepted?
QA.answer: Yes, you can use the Eco card everywhere where you can use the standard Wise card.

QA.question: Are the limits the same for the standard Wise card and the Eco card?
QA.answer: Yes, the limits are the same for the standard card and the Eco card.

QA.question: Where can I use my Wise card?
QA.answer: You can use your Wise card in most places where debit cards are accepted, except in specific countries depending on where your card was issued. You can also use it for online payments and cash withdrawals from ATMs.

QA.question: In which countries will my Wise card not work?
QA.answer: Your card won't work in countries such as Afghanistan, Belarus, Iran, Iraq, among others. Restrictions vary depending on where your card was issued (US, Indonesia, Malaysia, etc.).

QA.question: Can I use my Wise card for online payments?
QA.answer: Yes, you can use your Wise card for online payments. Some online payments may require 3D Secure (3DS) approval through the Wise app or a code sent by SMS or call.

QA.question: Does Wise support 3DS payments for cards issued in the US?
QA.answer: No, Wise does not support 3DS payments for cards issued in the US.

QA.question: Why was my online payment declined?
QA.answer: Your online payment might be declined if the website only accepts locally issued cards.

QA.question: Can I withdraw cash using my Wise card?
QA.answer: Yes, you can withdraw cash from most ATMs, except in specified countries depending on where your card was issued.

QA.question: How can I find an ATM that accepts Wise cards?
QA.answer: You can use the Mastercard ATM locator or Visa ATM locator to find an ATM that accepts Wise cards.

QA.question: Can I withdraw cash in the country where my card was issued if I have a debit card from Singapore or Canada?
QA.answer: If your debit card was issued in Singapore or Canada, you can't make ATM withdrawals in the country your card was issued.

QA.question: Can I use my Japan-issued Wise card in ATMs in Japan?
QA.answer: Yes, you might be able to use your Japan-issued Wise card at AEON, Family Mart, and Daily Yamazaki ATMs in Japan.

QA.question: How much are the spending fees for the Wise card?
QA.answer: Spending fees depend on whether the currency is in your account or not. If you have the currency, it’s free. If not, there’s a conversion fee. Please check the Terms of Use for your region for the latest information.

QA.question: Is there any fee to get a Wise card?
QA.answer: Wise might ask you to add money to your balance or pay a small fee to get the card.

QA.question: What are the cash withdrawal fees for the Wise card?
QA.answer: You get 2 free withdrawals up to 200 GBP total (or currency equivalent) per month. Additional withdrawals may have fees.

QA.question: Is there any fee to replace a Wise card?
QA.answer: You might need to pay a small fee to replace your card, which covers the cost of making and delivering a new one.

QA.question: How does currency conversion work for the Wise card in Brazil?
QA.answer: For Brazil cardholders, the smart conversion will not work when the BRL balance is involved in the transaction.

QA.question: Are spending fees for Wise card transactions in Belarus different?
QA.answer: Yes. Due to sanctions and recent developments, Wise uses the conversion rate set by the National Bank of the Republic of Belarus instead of the mid-market rate for BYN payments. The change is in effect from 16 May 2022 and only affects BYN payments.

QA.question: What happens if I spend money in a currency that I don't have in my account?
QA.answer: If you don't have the required currency in your account, Wise's Smart Conversion technology will automatically convert the balance for you that has the lowest conversion fee, or the one with the best exchange rate if fees are the same.

QA.question: Can I set a default or preferred balance to convert from?
QA.answer: No, you can't set a default or preferred balance to convert from.

QA.question: How can I calculate the conversion fees for card transactions?
QA.answer: You can calculate the conversion fees between different currencies for card transactions using Wise's pricing page.

QA.question: If I buy something for 100 EUR and have 150 EUR in my account, do I need to pay a conversion fee?
QA.answer: No, it's free to spend if you have enough balance in the required currency.

QA.question: If I buy something for 100 EUR and don't have a EUR account, what will happen?
QA.answer: Wise will convert the amount needed from your available balances and charge a conversion fee.

QA.question: If I buy something for 100 EUR and only have 90 EUR, but I have money in my USD account, how does the conversion work?
QA.answer: Wise will use the 90 EUR and convert the rest from your USD account, charging a conversion fee.

QA.question: Will the Smart Conversion feature work for Brazilian cards when the BRL account is involved?
QA.answer: No, the Smart Conversion feature will not work for Brazilian cards when the BRL account is involved. If you try to spend in a currency that you don't have and BRL is the only available currency, the transaction will be declined due to insufficient funds.

QA.question: What are the default and maximum spending limits for the Wise card?
QA.answer: Your Wise card comes with default and maximum limits that can be chosen in the Wise app or desktop version. Limits vary based on the cardholder's country and type of transaction.

QA.question: How do contactless payments work with the Wise card?
QA.answer: Contactless payments are common in Europe, UK, Australia, New Zealand, Japan, Singapore, or Canada. You might have to enter your PIN the first time you use it.

QA.question: Are there any ATM withdrawal limits for the Wise card?
QA.answer: Yes, different limits apply to ATM withdrawals depending on the cardholder's country. Note that ATMs may have their own limits and charge additional fees.

QA.question: When do the daily and monthly spending limits refresh for the Wise card?
QA.answer: Daily limits refresh every day at midnight, and monthly limits refresh on the first day of each month. Check the exact time in the app.

QA.question: Are mobile wallet transactions subject to spending limits?
QA.answer: Yes, transactions made by Google Pay, Apple Pay, Samsung Pay, Fitbit Pay, or Garmin Pay count towards your chip and PIN limits for UK and EU cardholders.

QA.question: Do Wise Business card spending limits differ from personal card limits?
QA.answer: Yes, the spending limits for the Wise Business card are different from personal card limits.

QA.question: How can I learn more about Wise Business card spending limits?
QA.answer: To learn more about the Wise Business card's spending limits, you can visit the dedicated webpage or contact Wise customer support.

QA.question: How can I change my Wise card spending limits?
QA.answer: You can change your spending limits on the app or website, by accessing your Card settings and selecting Account limits. Follow the provided steps to change to the maximum or default limits.

QA.question: What are the two spending limit settings on the Wise card?
QA.answer: There are two spending limit settings: the maximum and the default limit.

QA.question: How do I change my spending limits using the Wise app?
QA.answer: Open the app, go to Card, tap Manage payment methods, tap Account limits, select the limit you'd like to change, and tap the button at the bottom to change to the maximum or default limits.

QA.question: How do I change my spending limits on the Wise website?
QA.answer: Go to your Cards tab, select Account limits at the top, select the transaction type you'd like to change, and select the button at the bottom to change to the maximum or default limits.

QA.question: How can I check my Wise card details?
QA.answer: You can check your card details on the app or website if you live in eligible countries. For the app, go to Card, then select Card details. For the website, go to your Wise account, select the Cards tab, and then select Show card details.

QA.question: Can I use my card details online or with my mobile wallet before receiving the physical card?
QA.answer: Yes, you can use your card details online or with your mobile wallet before your physical card arrives if you live in eligible countries.

QA.question: What countries are eligible for viewing Wise card details on the app or website?
QA.answer: Eligible countries are Europe, the UK, Australia, New Zealand, Singapore, Malaysia, Japan, Brazil, and Canada.

QA.question: Is it necessary to enter my Wise password when checking my card details?
QA.answer: You may need to enter your Wise password, or use fingerprint or facial recognition, to view your card details on the app or website.

QA.question: Should I save my Wise card details on websites and apps?
QA.answer: Only save your card details with websites and apps you know and trust. Report any suspicious activity on your card immediately.

QA.question: How can I add a label to my Wise card?
QA.answer: Open your Wise account, go to the Card section, select the card, click on Set card label under Manage card section, type the label and tap Save.

QA.question: What is the maximum number of characters I can use in my Wise card label?
QA.answer: You can use up to 20 characters, including spaces and emojis, in your card label.

QA.question: Can I add labels to both my personal and business Wise cards?
QA.answer: Yes, this feature is available for all personal and business Wise cards.

QA.question: Is it possible to edit a label on my Wise card?
QA.answer: Yes, simply follow the same steps as adding a label and modify the text as needed.

QA.question: How can I remove a label from my Wise card?
QA.answer: Follow the same steps for adding a label, but delete the existing name and save without entering any characters.

QA.question: How much does it cost to withdraw cash with a Wise card?
QA.answer: You get 2 free withdrawals per calendar month. The fees you pay depend on your card's region and currency. If you withdraw cash in a currency you're not currently holding, we'll charge a conversion fee. Some ATMs may charge additional fees.

QA.question: What is the free withdrawal allowance, fixed fee, and variable rate for my region?
QA.answer: Please check our pricing page and set the correct location in the top right corner of the page to see the fees and rates for your region.

QA.question: How do I check my remaining free withdrawals and when they will refresh?
QA.answer: You can check this in the Wise app by going to Card > Manage payment methods > Spending Limits > ATM Withdrawals, or on the website by going to Card > Limits > ATM withdrawals.

QA.question: How can I avoid extra fees from the ATM?
QA.answer: To avoid extra fees, choose the local currency where the ATM is when prompted to select a currency.

QA.question: Can I use my Wise card for ATM withdrawals in Singapore, Canada, or Japan?
QA.answer: If your card was issued in Singapore or Canada, you can't make ATM withdrawals locally but can use your card for payments and overseas withdrawals. If your card was issued in Japan, you can use it for payments and overseas withdrawals, and at selected ATMs in Japan that accept international cards.

QA.question: Can I check my balance at an ATM with a Wise card?
QA.answer: You can check your balance at ATMs, the Wise app, and on the website, except for cards issued in the U.S.

QA.question: Will I be charged a conversion fee if I withdraw cash in a currency I'm not currently holding?
QA.answer: Yes, you'll be charged a conversion fee to convert the currency for you.

QA.question: Are the ATM withdrawal fees separate for each card on my account?
QA.answer: No, if you have multiple cards on your account, the fees apply per account.

QA.question: What happens to my ATM withdrawal fees if I change my registered address after moving to another country and order a new card?
QA.answer: Your cash withdrawal fees for all cards will be updated automatically to reflect the fees applicable to your new country of residence.

QA.question: How do I find my Wise card PIN if I've forgotten it?
QA.answer: You can check your PIN in the Wise app or website by going to your account, navigating to the 'Cards' section, and selecting 'Show PIN'. You may need to enter your Wise password, use fingerprint, or facial recognition to check your PIN.

QA.question: Can I change my Wise card PIN?
QA.answer: Yes, you can change your PIN. In the EEA and UK, you can change it at some ATMs. In the US, you can change it in the Wise app or website. Remember that you can only choose a 4-digit PIN.

QA.question: How do I change my PIN if I'm a US cardholder?
QA.answer: If you forget your PIN, you can set a new one in the Wise app or website by going to the 'Card' section, clicking on 'Change PIN', and typing the desired PIN number twice.

QA.question: What happens if I enter the wrong PIN 3 times?
QA.answer: If you enter the wrong PIN 3 times, we'll block it and you won't be able to use your card. To unblock your PIN, open your Wise app, go to the 'Card' section, and choose 'Unblock PIN'.

QA.question: How do I restore contactless functionality after unblocking my PIN?
QA.answer: After unblocking your PIN, you'll need to make a payment using your chip and PIN first to restore contactless functionality.

QA.question: How do I change my PIN on my Wise card?
QA.answer: For non-US cardholders, you may be able to change your PIN at an ATM that supports PIN changes for non-issuing bank cards. For US cardholders, you can change your PIN within the US by going to the Cards or Card section on the website or app, clicking on 'Change PIN', and entering the desired PIN number twice.

QA.question: Can Wise change my PIN for me?
QA.answer: No, Wise cannot change your PIN for you. You must either change it at an ATM or through the Wise website or app if you are a US cardholder.

QA.question: Is there a way to change my PIN if I am a non-US cardholder?
QA.answer: Non-US cardholders may be able to change their PIN at an ATM that supports PIN changes for cards other than those with the ATM's issuer.

QA.question: Can I change my PIN if I am a US cardholder?
QA.answer: Yes, if you are a US cardholder, you can change your PIN within the US by following the steps on the website or app under the 'Cards' or 'Card' section.

QA.question: What should I do if I've forgotten my PIN?
QA.answer: If you have forgotten your PIN, refer to the 'Learn what to do if you’ve forgotten your PIN' section on the Wise website or app for further instructions.

QA.question: What should I do if an ATM didn't give me my cash?
QA.answer: In most cases, the money will automatically be returned to your balance within a few minutes. If that doesn't happen, contact the ATM provider first or wait for the transaction to return to your account in 7 days if it's pending.

QA.question: How can I contact the ATM provider?
QA.answer: Find the contact number on the ATM and call them to report the issue. Have the transaction date, time, ATM code, and operation number ready when you call.

QA.question: What should I do if a transaction is pending?
QA.answer: If the transaction is marked as pending in your activity, the money should automatically return to your account in 7 days.

QA.question: What should I do if a transaction is completed?
QA.answer: If the transaction is marked as completed in your activity, submit a dispute.

QA.question: What should I choose if the ATM asks to convert for me?
QA.answer: Always say no to conversion, or choose to withdraw in the local currency.

QA.question: What happens if I let the ATM convert for me?
QA.answer: The ATM will often use an unfair exchange rate, charging you 6% more on average than if you withdraw without conversion.

QA.question: Why should I decline the ATM conversion?
QA.answer: If you decline the ATM conversion, Wise makes the conversion, and you won't be charged anything to convert if you already have that currency in your Wise account.

QA.question: What if I don't have the currency in my Wise account while withdrawing?
QA.answer: If you don't have that currency in your Wise account, Wise will convert from the currency you have that has the lowest conversion fee.

QA.question: How can I check the conversion fees for different currencies in my Wise account?
QA.answer: You can check the conversion fees here: https://wise.com/.

QA.question: How can I replace my Wise card?
QA.answer: You can replace your Wise card using the app or the web. In the app, go to the Card tab, tap on Replace Card, choose the reason, and tap on Replacement Card. On the web, click on Cards, select Replace card, and choose an option on the screen.

QA.question: What are the options when replacing my Wise card?
QA.answer: The options available when replacing your Wise card are: I lost my card, my card was stolen, my card was damaged, and support team suggested I should.

QA.question: What happens when I choose 'I lost my card' or 'My card was stolen'?
QA.answer: If you choose 'I lost my card' or 'My card was stolen', your card will be blocked and cancelled immediately, and you'll be able to order a new card.

QA.question: Can I continue using my damaged card if I request a replacement?
QA.answer: Yes, you can keep using your damaged card until the new one is activated.

QA.question: When will my new Wise card be delivered?
QA.answer: Delivery times depend on your region. For example, it takes 2-6 days for the UK, 14-21 working days for the US, and 3 working days for Singapore.

QA.question: Will I be reminded to replace my card before it expires?
QA.answer: Yes, if you regularly use your card, Wise will remind you to replace it before it expires.

QA.question: How do I cancel my Wise card?
QA.answer: To cancel your Wise card, get in touch with Wise's customer support.

QA.question: How do I replace my Wise digital card?
QA.answer: On the app, go to the Card tab, slide to the digital card you want to replace, and select Replace card. On the website, go to Cards, find the card you want to replace, and select Replace card.

QA.question: How many times a day can I get new card details?
QA.answer: You can get new card details up to 3 times a day.

QA.question: What is the limitation for creating digital cards in the United Kingdom?
QA.answer: If you are in the United Kingdom, you can only create 1 digital card per day.

QA.question: How do I delete my Wise digital card?
QA.answer: On the app, go to the Card tab, slide to the digital card you want to delete, and select Delete card. On the website, go to Cards, find the card you want to delete, and select Delete card.

QA.question: Can I still get a refund to my card if it was replaced or deleted?
QA.answer: Yes, you can still get a refund to your card even if it was replaced or deleted.

QA.question: How can I get a refund if my digital card was replaced or deleted?
QA.answer: Even if your card details were replaced or deleted, you can still receive a refund to your account. Provide the last four digits of the card found on the app by going to Home, selecting the transaction you want the refund for, and finding the last 4 digits next to Card ending in.

QA.question: Where can I find the last four digits of my digital card on the Wise app?
QA.answer: Go to Home, select the transaction you want the refund for, and find the last 4 digits next to Card ending in.

QA.question: How long does it take for a refund to arrive in my account?
QA.answer: It typically takes 5–10 working days for the money to arrive in your account.

QA.question: What should I do if I've been charged multiple times for the same transaction?
QA.answer: 1. Log in to your Wise account, 2. Go to Home to see your activity list, 3. Select the duplicate transaction(s) to check their status, and then follow the appropriate steps depending on the status of the transactions.

QA.question: Why do multiple charges happen?
QA.answer: Businesses might authorise multiple charges in error, or because of a technical problem.

QA.question: How long does it take for duplicate transaction money to be returned to my balance?
QA.answer: In most cases, the money for duplicate transactions is sent back to your balance within a week.

QA.question: What should I do if all the duplicate transactions are pending?
QA.answer: There’s nothing you need to do right now – you’ll have to wait for one of the transactions to go through. The money for the other pending transactions usually goes back to your account in 7 working days.

QA.question: What should I do if one transaction is completed and others are pending?
QA.answer: The money for the completed transaction has reached the business. The money for all the pending transactions will be automatically returned to your balance within 7 days. There’s nothing you need to do.

QA.question: What if all the duplicate transactions are completed?
QA.answer: The money for all these transactions is now with the business you paid. You'll need to contact them and ask for a refund. If they don’t do this, you can ask for a refund through Wise’s dispute form and provide any communication with them.

QA.question: Why isn't contactless working for my Wise card?
QA.answer: There could be several reasons: 1. If you've never used contactless, you need to use your card in an ATM or do a chip and PIN transaction first. 2. If you've used contactless before, you may have reached your spending limit. 3. If your card is from the US, you may need to activate it first. 4. If you got your US card before 16th December 2019, it may not work with contactless, but you can use mobile payment apps instead.

QA.question: How can I activate my Wise card from the US?
QA.answer: Once you get your card, go to the Cards section of your account and enter the 6-digit code that's on the card under your name.

QA.question: How can I enable contactless payments on my new Wise card?
QA.answer: You need to use your card in an ATM or do a chip and PIN transaction one time before contactless can work.

QA.question: How do I check or change my contactless spending limit?
QA.answer: You can check or change your contactless spending limit in the Wise app.

QA.question: Can I make contactless payments using a US Wise card issued before 16th December 2019?
QA.answer: Older US Wise cards don't work with contactless. However, you can add your card to Apple Pay, Google Pay, or Samsung Pay to make contactless payments with your phone.

QA.question: Why isn't my transaction showing in my activity list?
QA.answer: There could be several reasons such as the merchant not accepting cards issued in a different country, a technical issue with the merchant, the shop not asking Wise to authorize the payment, or the terminal being offline when the payment was made.

QA.question: What should I do if an online payment doesn't show in my activity list?
QA.answer: Try deleting your card details from the merchant's website, troubleshooting your browser, and making the payment again.

QA.question: What happens if my balance goes negative due to an offline terminal transaction?
QA.answer: You need to top up your balance to continue using Wise.

QA.question: Do some merchants only accept cards issued in their country?
QA.answer: Yes, this is often the case in the US, where many businesses only accept US cards.

QA.question: What can cause a transaction to not be authorized by Wise?
QA.answer: The merchant might not have asked Wise to authorize the payment, or there could have been a technical issue during the transaction.

QA.question: How can I reverse a transaction on my Wise card?
QA.answer: First, check the status of the transaction in your Wise app. If it's pending, you'll need to wait for the merchant's decision. If it's completed, get in touch with the merchant for a refund. If they won't cooperate, use our dispute form to request a chargeback with Visa or MasterCard.

QA.question: What should I do if my card transaction is marked as Pending?
QA.answer: You can't reverse a pending transaction, as the money has left your account but is waiting for the merchant to claim it. The merchant may reverse the transaction or collect your money, so wait for their decision.

QA.question: How can I check the status of a transaction on my Wise card?
QA.answer: 1. Log in to your Wise app, 2. Go to Home to see your activity list, and 3. Find the transaction you'd like to reverse and tap/click to check its status.

QA.question: What if the transaction is marked as Completed?
QA.answer: Contact the merchant, preferably in writing, to ask for a refund. If they won't cooperate, you can ask for a refund through our dispute form, which will require certain documentation to open a chargeback with Visa or MasterCard.

QA.question: What information and documentation is required when filling out the dispute form?
QA.answer: You'll need to provide documentation of your communication attempts with the merchant, the receipt for the transaction, and details about the purchased items and the situation, including dates. Providing all requested information will speed up the process and avoid additional requests for documentation.

QA.question: Why was my Wise card declined?
QA.answer: Reasons could include reaching your spending limit, using the wrong billing address, technical problems, unsupported transaction types, trying to spend in a country where the card doesn't work, card being frozen, or the card not being activated yet.

QA.question: How can I check or increase my spending limits?
QA.answer: In the app: Tap on Card, then Manage payment methods, then Account limits. On the web: Select Cards, then Account limits.

QA.question: What should I do if my card is declined due to technical problems?
QA.answer: Try deleting your card details from the merchant's website, troubleshooting your browser, and making the payment again.

QA.question: What if my card is declined for a type of transaction that Wise doesn't support?
QA.answer: You might need to pay with a different card if Wise's card isn't compatible with the merchant's payment platform, or if the transaction is blocked for security reasons.

QA.question: In which countries can I not use my Wise debit card?
QA.answer: Check the list of countries you can't use your card in on the Wise website.

QA.question: How do I unfreeze my Wise card?
QA.answer: In the app, tap on Card and then Defrost. On the website, follow the instructions to unfreeze your card.

QA.question: How do I activate my Wise card?
QA.answer: Follow the instructions provided in the app or on the Wise website to activate your card.

QA.question: What billing address should I use for online payments with my Wise card?
QA.answer: Use the address listed on your Wise account when entering your card details for online payments.

QA.question: How long do refunds to my Wise card usually take?
QA.answer: It typically takes 5–10 working days for the money to arrive in your account once the merchant has sent your refund.

QA.question: What should I do if I've been waiting for more than 10 working days for a refund?
QA.answer: Get in touch with the merchant first.

QA.question: Can Wise track or see my refunds?
QA.answer: No, Wise can't track or see refunds until the money arrives to them.

QA.question: What happens when Wise receives my refund?
QA.answer: Wise will automatically deposit the money directly into the balance it came from.

QA.question: What can a merchant do if I'm expecting money back from a pending transaction?
QA.answer: The merchant can cancel the pending transaction, do nothing and let the money return in 7 or 30 days, or complete the transaction and issue a refund as a new transaction.

QA.question: Why is my transaction showing as pending?
QA.answer: A transaction might appear as pending because transferring money from your account to the merchant goes through several steps and isn't always instant.
